abstract.text: A class that animates changes to views and allows the dynamic modification of those animations.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A

object lets you animate changes to views and dynamically modify your animations before they finish. With a property animator, you can run your animations from start to finish normally or you can turn them into interactive animations and control the timing yourself. The animator operates on animatable properties of views, such as the
, and
properties, creating the needed animations from the blocks you provide.
When creating a property animator object, you specify the following:
A block containing code that modifies the properties of one or more views.
The timing curve that defines the speed of the animation over the course of its run.
The duration (in seconds) of the animation.
An optional completion block to execute when the animations finish.
In your animation blocks, set the value of an animatable property to the final value you want reflected by that view. For example, if you want to fade out a view, you would set its alpha property to
in your block. The property animator object creates an animation that adjusts the value of that property from its initial value to the new value that you specified in your block.

The speed at which the value of a property changes is controlled by the timing curve you specify when creating the property animator. Property animators include support for the built-in UIKit animation curves such as linear, ease-in, and ease-out. You can also use a cubic Bezier curve or a spring function to control the timing of the animations.
If you create your animator using one of the standard initialization methods, you must explicitly start your animations by calling the
method. If you want to start the animations immediately after the creation of your animator, use the
method instead of the standard initializers.
This class adopts the
and
protocols, which define the methods for starting, stopping, and modifying your animations. For more information about the methods of those protocols, see
and
A property animator gives you programmatic control over the timing and execution of the animations. Specifically, you can:
Start, pause, resume, and stop animations; see the methods of the
protocol.
Add animation blocks after the original animations start using the
and
methods.
Scrub through a paused animation by modifying the
property.
Change the animation’s direction using the
property.
Modify the timing and duration of a partially complete animation by pausing the animation and using the
method to finish it.
Most of the basic behavior is controlled by the properties of the

protocol, which this class adopts. Use those methods and properties to start, pause, resume, and stop the animations. You can also use them to scrub through the animation and change its direction. Use the methods and properties of this class to modify the animation blocks themselves and to update the timing information.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
The view’s alpha value.
The center point of the view’s frame rectangle.
The frame rectangle, which describes the view’s location and size in its superview’s coordinate system.
Specifies the transform applied to the view, relative to the center of its bounds.
An interface for implementing custom animator objects.
The completion percentage of the animation.
A Boolean value indicating whether the animation is running in the reverse direction.
Starts the animation from its current position.
An interface for modifying an animation while it’s running.
A class that animates changes to views and allows the dynamic modification of those animations.
Adds the specified animation block to the animator.
Adds the specified animation block with a delay.
Adds the specified completion block to the animator.
Adjusts the timing and duration of a paused animation.
The delay (in seconds) after which the animations begin.
The total duration (in seconds) of the main animations.
Initializes the animator object with a cubic Bézier timing curve.
Initializes the animator with a built-in UIKit timing curve.
Initializes the animator object with spring-based timing information.
Initializes the animator object with a custom timing curve object.
A Boolean value indicating whether the animator is interruptible and can be paused or stopped.
A Boolean value indicating whether your app manages hit-testing while animations are in progress.
A Boolean value indicating whether views receive touch events while animations are running.
A Boolean value that indicates whether a completed animation remains in the active state.
Creates and returns an animator object that begins running its animations immediately.
A Boolean value indicating whether a paused animation scrubs linearly or uses its specified timing information.
The information used to determine the timing curve for the animation.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
